If Decline Continues

End In Sight For ROTC
By WALTER MOORE
A staggering decrease in
ROTC enrollment for this year
may force a discontinuance of
ROTC at Hopkins.
Enrollment in the program
fails to meet official Army
standards. According to Colonel
Eleazor Parmly, "This present
year's enrollment could put the
ROTC program in jeopardy.
End Program?
"If the average graduating
class should fall below fifteen
members, I would recommend
that ROTC be discontinued at
Hopkins," said Parmly. The only
real remedies which would save
the ending of ROTC on Hopkins
campus would be an increase in

ROTC scholarship awardees or a
removal of students deferments.
"A general resurgence in
patriotic fevor would be bound
to increase enrollment as well,"
stated Parmly. Causes for the
decrease were the removal of
academic credit from the ROTC
program and the anti-military
attitudes created by the Vietnam
war.
Revitalization
In response to plummeting,
enrollment the ROTC staff will
attempt to revitalize the
program. "One helluva a lot
more interesting courses are
being planned," asserted the
ROTC director. Mountaineering
and Orienteering, as well as the
rifle club, are being opened to

non-ROTC students. The weekly
drill practices will be combined
into one monthly four hour
session. And guest speakers will
be invited to speak on topics
ranging from the Far East to
military warfare.
Sharp Drop
But the fact remains that
enrollment is down 43 percent
from last year's 96 ROTC
cadets. Official army policy
states that less than 100 cadets
in a freshman ROTC class
constitutes reason for
abandonment of the program.

76th Year

First Black Prof Chosen
Dr. Wayman E. Scott has
been appointed Arts and
Sciences first full-time black
professor.
The new assistant professor in
Earth and Planetary Sciences
said of his appointment,"I think
that I was in the right place at
the right time. There just aren't
that many black guys to hire
that are qualified, and those that
are qualified have lots of offers."
Offers
"The fact is that Scott came
along and he's good. The fact
that he was black allowed us to
hire him," said Owen M.Phillips,
chairman of Earth and Planetary
Sciences, who hired Scott. "We
have made offers to other black
professors before. It doesn't
represent a revolution on the
part of the University. It is just
that we were lucky to have
gotten him."
Compliance
The University as a whole
must hire one black professor
for each of its departments in
order to comply with a program
filed with Health, Education and
Welfare in June 1970. Without
compliance the University would
lose all of its federal funding
within five to seven years
according to regulation of the
1964 Civil Rights Act and
Executive Order 11246.
Latest figures from last year
reveal that there are eight black
professors out of the 1285
employed. Dr. Scott is the first
to hold an appointment in the
Arts and Sciences division.
Aberdeen
Scott has worked at the
Army's Ballistics Research
Lalloratory at the Aberdeen
Proving Grounds since 1956. He
continues to work there in his
primary field of interest, fluid
mechanics, while teaching a
seminar in fluid mechanics and
an undergraduate course in

Wayman Scott
planetary astronomy during his
afternoons at Homewood.
His work at Aberdeen is

centered on the way that two
harmless gases are combined to
create a toxic gas that can be
used militarily. He stressed that
the work is designed as a
preventive measure.
Scott commented that he
wanted to have contact with
undergraduates, especially black
students, lie would like to be
able to attend Black Student
Union meetings.
Prior to joining the staff at
the Aberdeen Proving Grounds
he was an instructor in physics
first at Tuskegee Institute and
then at Morgan State College.
There he maintained that it is
very difficult to attract white
students, and particularly white
professors."A white professor in
a black school in a small town is
looked down upon."

Gov't. Links Study Stalled
By DON LASSUS
Action has yet to be taken on
the investigation of University
ties with the government
ordered by the Board of
Trustees last October.
Former president Lincoln
Gordon was directed to make
the study last fall following the
Trustees' decision to lift the ban
on military recruitment and the
ensuing controversy over
Hopkins' dependence on
government funds.
"I have not found that Dr.
Gordon and his colleagues did
any substantial work on the
report," stated Dr. Steven
Muller,Provost.
Muller also indicated that the
present administration has no
plans to begin work on the
investigation. "Dr. Eisenhower
and I have no plans to raise the
question with the Board," said
Muller.
Muller asserted that the

administration was delaying its
plans on the report until "we see
what the Federal Government is
going to do to aid to
universities."
"At present there is a change
in the Education Lobby in
Congress and everything is up in
the air," stressed Muller. "We
believe it would be wise to delay
the study." He added that
President Eisenhower was paying
"top attention" to finances at
this point.
Muller stated that another
similar report was started in the
spring of 1970 by Gordon's
office. The study, conducted by
Wayne Anderson, was recently
submitted to the Provost.
"The report was very
incomplete," commented
Muller. "The statement
summarized things that everyone
already knows." According to
Muller, all that exists of the
Anderson report is a working

draft and it has been sent back
to Anderson for more work.
The question of Hopkins'
relations with federal funding
exploded into the major issue in
the protest over the Trustee
decision to end the ban on
recruitment imposed in the
spring of 1970.
Last October the Trustees
overturned the referendum on
the grounds that the University
would lose valuable funds
totaling $3 million dollars
annually in Defense Department
money.
The grants stipulated that
military recruitment _must be
allowed on the campus in order
to receive the DOD funds which
make up a major portion of the
University budget.
In a referendum of the
Homewood community at the
end of the May 1970 strike the
majority called for an end to
military recruiting on campus.

Architect for Levering Hall Addition Chosen
By DANIEL EPSTEIN
Plans to build a new student
union in the form of an addition
to Levering Hall have solidified.
An _architect, Donald Sickler,
has been commissioned to design
the new wing. He will work with
John McElwee, Director of
Physical Plant Planning, and a
special committee which is now
being set up. This committee
will consist of two
undergraduates, to be selected
by the Student Council; two
graduate students, to be selected
by the Graduate Student
Organization; two faculty
members, to be selected by the
Steering Committee for the
Faculty General Assembly, and
two Administration workers.

The actual plans for the addition
consist of a new wing to be
added to .the North side of
Levering Hall, where the small
parking lot stands. The wing will
have three stories, and will make
Levering Hall more symmetric.
The basement floor will have
game rooms and music rooms.
The ground floor will be an
enlargement of the current
dining space and the third floor
will have three large rooms fos
"general social purposes."
The entire project will consist
of three phases: the first one
will be the three-level addition;
the second one, if money
permits, will be a general
remodeling of existing facilities;
and the third is a possible third

floor over the Great Hall which
will tie in to Chester's Place and
enlarge the third floor.

plans was made possible through
the generosity of the late Dr.
Norman J. Small, a former
alumnus and instructor at

unrestricted grant of nearly
$280,000 to this University.
President Milton Eisenhower
:recommended that this gift be
used to initiate a fund for the
purpose of building a Student
Union and the Board of Trustees
approved the recommendation.

Dorm Food Gripes Heard
By JACKIE DOWD
The managers of Prophet
Food Co., the new dormitory
food service, assert they are
trying to satisfy students and
end the numerous complaints
that have been coming in.
Chief complaints have been
the poor quality of the food, the
amount of starch in it, lack of
suitable desserts and the length
of the lines.
ARA Slater, former food
service company in the Dining
Hall, left last year due to
financial difficulties. Unlike
Levering Hall where each meal is
Paid for separately, the Dining
Hall has a mandatory food fee
covering all meals for the year,
thus assuring the food
contractor of a certain income.
M. P. Francesco, city-manager
of Prophet, commented on the
food quality, "There exists an
internal problem of re-training
the employees to prepare food
in an adequate manner."
At this time, Prophet has no
financial statement to release.
Francesco explained that they
have not been here long enough
to be able to comment on their
financial status.
The Food Committee of the
Dormitory Student's
Representative Council is
collecting proposals and
opinions and will present them
to Prophet in the near future.
According to Francesco, Prophet
wants to work with the Food
Committee to find out What the
students want.
Ray High, manager, said
Whenever you deal with the
Public, you have problems. But
there's a difference between
something not being good and
not liking it." Both managers
claim to eat the food themselves.
Prophet has standard recipes
Prepared and packaged, and the
managers stressed that they-buy
only U.S. Grade A canned goods
,and U.S. Choice meats.
The problem is, as stated by
Francesco, "The student is used
to home cooking, and you can't
Please everybody with
institutional cooking." But, High
explained, "Each day we're here
We're getting to know what the
students like, and we can serve

accordingly."
Bob Murcko, chairman of the
Food Committee, remarked,
"When I spoke to Mr. High in
the beginning of the year, I told
him if the students didn't like
the food, he'd know about it.
It's our mission to make sure the
student voice is heard."
Certain complaints have
already been answered but
others have no solution. A
typical complaint concerns the
amount of starch in the food.
Francesco commented, "The
student today is more diet
conscious, but when he makes
his own selection, he goes heavy
on starches anyway." He added
that a balanced meal is served in
the Dining Hall, containing all
seven of the basic food
_requirements.
Another complaint was the
length of the lines. Francesco
explained that there was not too
much that could be done about
it. Food selections are pre-plated

to speed up lines, but a sudden
flow of students slows down the
process.
A request was made to make
up a menu a week in advance.
and according to Francesco this
will be 'done, subject to change
due to the availability of
products.
Students also wanted more
desserts, and as a result pudding,
jello, either pie or ice cream and
fresh fruit are now available.
Murcko stated the purpose of
the Food Committee is to bring
student complaints to Prophet,
and to see that they hold up to
all parts of their contract.
The committee will also
investigate the nutritional value
of the food served and the
method of preparation.
All suggestions and
complaints will be heard Friday
evenings in the Dining Hall.
They will then be discussed with
the manager of Prophet to seek
improvements.

ROTC decline
ROTC's own unattractiveness may result in what years
of protest have failed to produce: the end of ROTC on
campus. It seems that there are so few people graduating
or entering the program that it is not meeting Federal
requirements. ROTC director Col. Eleazor Parmly may
even recommend the ending of the program if the
graduating class falls below 15, as it seems likely to do
within the next year or two.
All those guerilla theaters, leaflets, committees and
angry statements have not done as much to kill ROTC as
such mundane items as the loss of academic credit or lack
of scholarships. Of course, protests created the
anti-military attitudes which helped make ROTC cadets
feel like pariahs. Nationally, freshman enrollment in the
three ROTC branches has dropped 70 percent.
The hostility to the military is among the most welcome
changes in values of recent years, and the gradual death of
the ROTC program is a cause for hope. But efforts by
some educational organizations to "reform" ROTC are
both useless and harmful; institutions as deep-rooted and
destructive as the military are not changed by the addition
of some college-trained officers.
We should not, of course, simply wait for Parmly to
decree the end of ROTC when he gets around to it in a few
years. Constant pressure needs to be applied so that all of
the University's ties to the military are ended.

Government funding
It is now official that the student strike of spring 1970
was an absurd exercise of frustration. Despite the apparent
sweeping victory of the referendum which threw military
recruiting off campus, despite the seeming radicalization of
an otherwise apathetic campus, revelations this week show
that all of the activity was for naught. The students who
participated in that struggle understood and didn't object
when actions by a military-oriented Congress forced
Hopkins to reinstate military recruiting, but everyone
involved, radicals and trustees alike, pointed to the bigger
problem that caused the difficulty, the University's
increasing financial dependence on government funds.
Thus, in the soberest of terms, the Board and President
Gordon ordered a study made of Hopkins' ties with the
government. A step in the right direction, at least. But now
we find out that even that small step is being ignored. A
presidential assistant apparently re-copied a few
News-Letter articles and tried to pass it off as the
large-scale study, but even the Provost admitted that this
would not do, adding that the current administration has
no plans for pursuing the idea. And so Hopkins will
continue to depend on the government for over half of its
budget, and the next time a crisis arises, perhaps another
study will be commissioned. Even when students point out
problems that are generally agreed to be issues worthy of
study, their efforts turn out to be in vain.

ROTC decline
ROTC's own unattractiveness may result in what years
of protest have failed to produce: the end of ROTC on
campus. It seems that there are so few people graduating
or entering the program that it is not meeting Federal
requirements. ROTC director Col. Eleazor Parmly may
even recommend the ending of the program if the
graduating class falls below 15, as it seems likely to do
within the next year or two.
All those guerilla theaters, leaflets, committees and
angry statements have not done as much to kill ROTC as
such mundane items as the loss of academic credit or lack
of scholarships. Of course, protests created the
anti-military attitudes which helped make ROTC cadets
feel like pariahs. Nationally, freshman enrollment in the
three ROTC branches has dropped 70 percent.
The hostility to the military is among the most welcome
changes in values of recent years, and the gradual death of
the ROTC program is a cause for hope. But efforts by
some educational organizations to "reform" ROTC are
both useless and harmful; institutions as deep-rooted and
destructive as the military are not changed by the addition
of some college-trained officers.
We should not, of course, simply wait for Parmly to
decree the end of ROTC when he gets around to it in a few
years. Constant pressure needs to be applied so that all of
the University's ties to the military are ended.

Government funding
It is now official that the student strike of spring 1970
was an absurd exercise of frustration. Despite the apparent
sweeping victory of the referendum which threw military
recruiting off campus, despite the seeming radicalization of
an otherwise apathetic campus, revelations this week show
that all of the activity was for naught. The students who
participated in that struggle understood and didn't object
when actions by a military-oriented Congress forced
Hopkins to reinstate military recruiting, but everyone
involved, radicals and trustees alike, pointed to the bigger
problem that caused the difficulty, the University's
increasing financial dependence on government funds.
Thus, in the soberest of terms, the Board and President
Gordon ordered a study made of Hopkins' ties with the
government. A step in the right direction, at least. But now
we find out that even that small step is being ignored. A
presidential assistant apparently re-copied a few
News-Letter articles and tried to pass it off as the
large-scale study, but even the Provost admitted that this
would not do, adding that the current administration has
no plans for pursuing the idea. And so Hopkins will
continue to depend on the government for over half of its
budget, and the next time a crisis arises, perhaps another
study will be commissioned. Even when students point out
problems that are generally agreed to be issues worthy of
study, their efforts turn out to be in vain.
